article.headline: Miami rallies to send game to OT, win it
article.linkText: Hurricanes stop slide, upend Terps in overtime
article.story:
CORAL GABLES, Fla. -- Miami's Will Frisby was excited about
shooting free throws with the game on the line.

	   Frisby made a pair of free throws with 0.8 seconds left in
overtime to lift Miami past Maryland (No. 24 ESPN/USA Today; No. 22 AP) 75-73 on Saturday.

	   "I wasn't really nervous," Frisby said. "I was more like
happy thinking, 'Wow, I'm going to win this game for us.' "

	   It was the first win in three games for Miami (14-7, 5-5
Atlantic Coast Conference), which led for nearly the entire game
but had to rally at the end of regulation and in the final second
of overtime.

	   "It's a great win," said Miami coach Frank Haith. "It puts us
right back in the middle of things in terms of the race. We're 5-5
in the league. That's where you want to be."

	   Guillermo Diaz scored 27 points to pace the Hurricanes.

	   "We needed this game," Diaz said. "We got it done."

	   Maryland (13-7, 4-5) lost its second consecutive game after a
pair of wins over Duke and Georgia Tech.

	   Miami trailed for just 27 seconds of the first half, and
maintained its lead until Chris McCray made a 3-pointer from the
right wing to give Maryland a 60-57 lead with 6:07 remaining.

	   McCray led Maryland with 23 points, including 20 in the second
half and overtime. Mike Jones, who scored 14, was the only other
Maryland player in double figures.

	   Maryland held the lead until 2:58, when Diaz made a 3-pointer to
put Miami up 64-62. But the Terrapins went back in front just over
a minute later when John Gilchrist's 3-pointer gave them a 65-64
lead with 1:44 remaining.

	   Diaz bailed the Hurricanes out again, blowing past two defenders
for a layup and a 66-65 lead at 1:17.

	   Maryland called a timeout, and Gilchrist missed a long 3-pointer
that was rebounded by Miami's Robert Hite with 45 seconds left.

	   The Hurricanes let the game clock wind down to 18 seconds before
Diaz missed a deep 3-pointer. But Anthony King snared the rebound,
and was fouled by Will Bowers with 15.3 seconds remaining.

	   King missed the first free throw but made the second, giving
Miami a 67-65 lead. But the Hurricanes allowed Travis Garrison to
get a rebound of a miss by Gilchrist on the other end, and the
junior forward made both free throws to tie the game at 67 with 3.9
seconds left.

	   Diaz took the inbound pass and made a desperate runner from NBA
3-point range, but failed to get the shot off before the buzzer.

	   "They said it didn't count," Diaz said. "I just had to forget
about it."

	   In overtime, Diaz scored Miami's first four points to give the
Hurricanes a 71-69 lead. Frisby had a chance to put Miami up 75-70,
but missed a dunk attempt at 1:28.

	   McCray's 3-pointer 14 seconds later tied the game at 73. Diaz
missed a rushed 3-pointer with 42 seconds remaining, and Nik
Caner-Medley appeared to put Maryland up 75-73 with 14 seconds
left.

	   But Caner-Medley was called for an offensive foul after knocking
Frisby to the floor.

	   "What are you gonna do?" Maryland coach Gary Williams said.
"Get a technical? The referee called a charge. There was
contact."

	   Hite missed a short jumper with 3 seconds to go, but Frisby
grabbed the rebound and was fouled by Jones with 0.8 seconds left.

	   "For the first time in the game, they shot an airball," said
Williams. "That's our rebound. We don't get it, we foul them, and
they make the foul shots and win the game."

	   Frisby made both free throws, and McCray failed to get a
desperation 3-pointer off before the final buzzer.

	   "It's great for us," said Frisby. "We'll live it up today.
It's a good win, but we know we have bigger things ahead of us."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
